utterances: That's right.
There's been a lot of talk about the closeness between Alberto Gonzales and President Bush with both of them going back to early days in Texas.
But it seems that no one could ever have been closer than Robert Kennedy to JFK.
It doesn't get closer than your brother.
Well, I think that's why we really need to understand what we mean by independence from the White House.
It need not be someone who is a complete unknown to the president or someone who does not share at all the president's political vision.

But you have to have someone who can have the candor and the honesty to confront the president, to - or, in a nice way, to tell the president that what he or she is planning is not appropriate or crosses a line.

I think what was different with Bobby Kennedy was that he did have that kind of relationship with his brother and he did have some experience, political experience that helped sensitize him to what some of these issues are.
And this is an area where Alberto Gonzales really fall short.

He did not have previous experience as a prosecutor, he did not have previous experience in elected office, and he did not have a separate constituency not or he did not have a separate constituency outside groups that helped to support him as is his predecessor John Ashcroft.
Nancy Baker is an associate professor of government at New Mexico State University in Las Cruces.
Thanks very much for speaking with us.
Oh, I've been delighted.
Thank you very much.
And one more note.
This weekend, the White House is considering congressional requests for documents and witnesses back in shed light on the firing of the eight U.S.
attorneys, but the White House suggests that complying with the request might violate principles of executive privilege.
You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
Voters also cast their ballots in large parts of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip today.
Palestinians there were electing municipal councils.
More than 900 seats were up for grabs.
There's been stiff competition between the Fatah movement of Palestinian Leader Mahmoud Abbas and the Islamist group Hamas.
Hamas candidates swept the polls in Gaza during an earlier round of voting.
The contest in the West Bank is much closer with early returns suggesting a narrow victory for Fatah.
The face-off between the two will continue in July when parliamentary elections are scheduled.
NPR's Linda Gradstein was in one West Bank village for today's vote and has our report.
Supaya Hussein(ph), a housewife and mother of five, voted at the Usra Girls School(ph) in the village of Sinjil.
At the entrance to the polling station, Hussein was handed a ballot with 27 names and told to choose up to 11 for the local council.
She hinted that she had voted for candidates from Hamas.
(Foreign language spoken)
`I voted for those who are religious and pray at the mosque,' she said.
`I want people who are honest and who will help our village.'
We can't just rebuild them, he says.
They're lost.
That's why archaeologists feel a sense of urgency here and at other sites as they work around the clock to recover what they can.
Kirk Siegler, NPR News, Kathmandu.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
Renee Montagne is on assignment in Afghanistan this month.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
Good morning.
Who had been kind of shoved away from power at that moment - right?
Well, this week, of course, President Trump - unexpectedly, apparently - reached a deal with congressional Democrats to raise the debt limit and fund hurricane relief.
A lot of members of your party are reportedly aghast.
How do you feel?
Actually, I believe the agreement that the president reached was fair.

Now, and the very members who are complaining about the deal that the president reached on the debt ceiling were upset that the debt ceiling was only to be extended for three months, rather than 18 months.

But truth be told, those same members wouldn't have voted for the debt ceiling, either three months or 18 months, thereby empowering Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi, who will be helping put up the votes for the debt ceiling.
So the president, I think, recognized that leverage and negotiated with them.
I would have preferred a longer debt ceiling as well, closer to 18 months.
But I do recognize the reality of the situation.
We're providing relief to the hurricane victims from Harvey.
And we're keeping the government running for three months.
And we have a three-month debt ceiling.
The agreement was reasonable.
And again, those very same members who are complaining about it would have never voted for a better deal anyway.
I have to ask.
You're from a swing district.
I gather you spoke with Speaker Ryan before news of your declining to run for re-election got out.
Did the speaker try and change your mind?
Well, I did speak with both Speaker Ryan and Steve Stivers.
He's chair of the Congressional Campaign Committee.
And they were both, I believe, fair to say, disappointed in what - would certainly prefer that I run for re-election.
There's no question about that.
But they understand that, you know, these decisions are not just about politics, they're personal.
And they respect that, but they clearly would prefer that I run for re-election.
You would have had a tough primary though, right?
There's been rallies against you and...
Oh, no. There was a rally last week, but it was a - that was a buffoon bus.
And it was a - it was a freak show, to be honest with you.
I mean, it really was bizarre.
I mean, it was a bunch of people from out of town in a bus, you know, yelling and screaming.
I mean, it really was not much of anything, but...
I just want to interject.
They may not share that characterization, but go ahead please, sir.
Yeah, I'm sure they don't, but it's accurate (laughter).
But I really had no serious challenge from the left or the right.
My re-election prospects looked quite good, actually.
Most of my colleagues have multiple opponents.
You know, I had just one who announced in the right, and I had one who announced from the left, but neither of whom are particularly viable.
Why leave when, arguably, your voice - it's more important than ever that you be heard?
Well, I have discussed with my family for - since 2013 about leaving Congress at some point.
I never expected to serve more than five or six terms in the House, voters permitting.
And I'm in my seventh term.
I've been a committee chair.
I'm a subcommittee chair on appropriations, a cardinal.
I like that.
But at the same time, I want to leave at the top of my game.
And I feel that I can provide a voice for the sensible center, not just inside Congress, but from the outside as well.
And so I'm really looking forward to the next phase of my life.
I have to ask you in the 30 seconds we have left, are moderate Republicans a dwindling breed?
Well, no. I mean, there are a lot of center-right Republicans, not enough, as far as I'm concerned, in Congress.
But this is where the country is.
I really believe this country does like us working from the center out.
I truly believe that.
And by the way, I just wanted to thank all the voters who supported me all these years.
And it's just been a great - it's been the - a responsibility and honor of a lifetime to serve in Congress.
And I've just thoroughly enjoyed it.
Congressman Dent of Pennsylvania, thanks so much for being with us.
Thank you.
The time for turkey, pies and football has come and gone.
But there are still some things to look forward to because it is time to play The Puzzle.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
I am joined by the puzzle editor of The New York Times and WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle master Will Shortz.
Hey, Will.
Hey.
Good morning, Linda.
There's a little more football this afternoon, isn't there?
I was going to say - in my household, there is a lot more football.
(LAUGHTER)
So anyway, we just wrapped up a two-week creative challenge to listeners.
Could you remind us what that was?
Yeah.
The object was to write a conundrum that starts, what is the difference between, in which the answer involves a transposition of words.
And I said change of spelling in the words was allowed.
Well, we got more than 1,500 conundrums.
I read every one of them.
Entries were judged on their sense, naturalness of wording, humor, elegance and overall effect.
I especially like ones with unexpected twists.
Before I read you the winner, let me read you a few runners-up.
From Brett Hunkins of Okemos, Mich., he wrote, what is the difference between Sting and a retired EPA official?
One led The Police while the other policed the lead.
Oh, dear (laughter).
Mark Mikula of Bristol, R.I., wrote, what's the difference between a libertarian and a charitable pharmacist?
One leaves you alone while the other loans Aleve.
And Amy Higgins of Ann Arbor, Mich., wrote, what's the difference between a straight-A student and a car safety inspector?
One breaks the curve on a test while the other tests the brakes on a curve.
Well, that's just brilliant.
Anyway, the winner - and I chose this because it was simple and stupid and it made me laugh.
It came from Roxanne Abrams of Skokie, Ill.
And she submitted, what is the difference between a priest and his dog?
The priest wears pants and a collar while the dog wears a collar and pants.
(Laughter) That is very good (laughter).
We have Roxanne on the line now with us.
Congratulations on that.
Thank you so much.
How remarkable to be with you both.
So how did you go about crafting your riddle?
Every inch of France is mapped from the center of Notre Dame.
People tell time by the toll of its bells.

The cathedral has been the scene of royal coronations and the crowning of cardinals, while its grounds are the setting for protest, concerts, picnics, painters, pickup soccer games and countless strolls by families, tourists and lovers.
After all these centuries, Notre Dame is still a working church.
It hums with masses, baptisms, communions and millions of murmured, silent, everyday prayers, uttered over flickering vigil candles.
